text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Monday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- Among 1,351 candidates to parliament there are 12 whose property and income exceed one million litas, 158 had no property at all, 55 had no income last year and 14 had neither income nor property, according to reports on candidates property and income to the Central Election Committee.
- The central bank issued permission last Friday to Snoras Bank to establish two representative offices in Moscow and St.Petersburg.

- Energy officials are failing to meet a planned target of gathering 500,000 tones of heating oil before the heating season begins. Lietuvos Energija volumes are now 293,000 tonness of heating oil, sufficient to continue heating for only two months.

- Prime Minister Mindaugas Stankevicius met Belarussian premier Michail Cigir and suggested the Belarus chemical firm Soligorsk invest into Klaipeda port. Cigir said Belarus was interested in buying electricity from Lithuania but that energy officials at home were lobbying against it.

- European Commission ambassador Henrik Schiegelow said Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas will receive clear confirmation that Lithuania is expected in the European Union during his visit to Brussels this week.

- The panel taking bids for a contract to build a nuclear waste storage facility at the Ignalina nuclear power plant excluded Canada's Ontario Hydro and the head of the commission said that the other two bidders, AECL and GNB, could be asked to work together since their tenders were similar.
- President Brazauskas heads to Brussels for a four day working visit on Tuesday to meet the leaders of NATO and European Union to discuss the prospects of Lithuania joining the two organisations.
- Denmark was positive over the suggestion by Brazauskas to hold a joint conference of the Baltic countries and European Union on cooperation and regional security.
